virtual servers

Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) is a popular web service offered by Amazon Web Services (AWS) that allows you to create and manage virtual machines, known as instances, in the AWS infrastructure. EC2 provides resizable and scalable computing capacity in the cloud

Easily scale instances up or down based on traffic or application demands.
Variety of Instance Types:

Offers different types of instances optimized for compute, memory, storage, or GPU requirements.
Operating System Choice:

Choose from a wide range of operating systems like Linux, Windows, or bring your own license.
Cost-Effective:

Pay only for the compute capacity you use (pay-as-you-go pricing).
Use Reserved Instances or Spot Instances for cost savings.
Customizable:

Configure CPU, memory, storage, and networking resources for your instance.
Secure:

Includes features like security groups (firewall rules) and encryption.

topics.title: Implementing upper_bound() and lower_bound() in C
Binary Search
topics.note:
What is Binary Search Algorithm?
Binary search is a search algorithm used to find the position of a target value within a sorted array. It works by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half until the target value is found or the interval is empty. The search interval is halved by comparing the target element with the middle value of the search space.

topics.title: Selection sort
topics.note:
Selection Sort is a comparison-based sorting algorithm. It sorts an array by repeatedly selecting the smallest (or largest) element from the unsorted portion and swapping it with the first unsorted element. This process continues until the entire array is sorted.

First we find the smallest element and swap it with the first element. This way we get the smallest element at its correct position.
Then we find the smallest among remaining elements (or second smallest) and swap it with the second element.
We keep doing this until we get all elements moved to correct position.

topics.title: Insertion Sort Algorithm
topics.note: Insertion sort is a simple sorting algorithm that works by iteratively inserting each element of an unsorted list into its correct position in a sorted portion of the list. It is like sorting playing cards in your hands. You split the cards into two groups: the sorted cards and the unsorted cards. Then, you pick a card from the unsorted group and put it in the right place in the sorted group.

QuickSort is a sorting algorithm based on the Divide and Conquer that picks an element as a pivot and partitions the given array around the picked pivot by placing the pivot in its correct position in the sorted array.
topics.title: Quick Sort
Prefix sum
topics.note: Given an array arr[] of size N, find the prefix sum of the array. A prefix sum array is another array prefixSum[] of the same size, such that the value of prefixSum[i] is arr[0] + arr[1] + arr[2] . . . arr[i].

topics.title: moors voting algorithm
topics.note:
What is Moore's Voting Algorithm?
Mooreâ€™s Voting Algorithm (or Boyer-Moore Majority Vote Algorithm) is a technique used to find the majority element in an array in O(n) time and O(1) space. It works by cancelling out elements that are not in the majority, leaving only the potential majority element.

The Accept header in HTTP requests is used by the client to tell the server which media types (formats) it is willing to receive. This helps the server determine how to respond with the correct content type. The server can then decide to return data in a format that's acceptable to the client.

Accept: application/json. --- for json 
Accept: text/html            ---  for html pages
Accept: text/plain           --- for plain text
Accept: application/xml.  --- for XML
Accept: application/pdf.   --- for pdf files
Accept: image/png
Accept: image/jpeg
Accept: image/gif.          --- for images
Accept: application/octet-stream   --- for binary data
Accept: */*.    ---- will accept anything

quality factors can be used to specify the preference
Accept: application/json;q=0.9, text/html;q=0.8, application/xml;q=0.7

so more threads means OS require to do more context switching..
and more process means more memmory usage as each process gets independent memory.

Node.js is a single-threaded runtime that uses an event-driven, non-blocking I/O model. When a request is received, the main thread processes it. If an I/O operation (like reading a file or querying a database) is required, Node.js offloads the task to libuv's worker threads and continues handling other requests. Once the I/O operation is complete, its callback is pushed into the event loop's callback queue and executed in the next event loop cycle. This allows Node.js to handle multiple concurrent requests efficiently without blocking the main thread

topics.title: Thread pool
topics.note:
Thread pool is used to run the code which blocks the main thread, and it contains a pool of thread.

The default size is 4.  we can increase using PROCESS.ENV.UV_THREADPOOL_SIZE = 5;

topics.title: network io
topics.note:
HTTP request is a network io operation and not a CPU bound operation.
It does not use the thread pool.

libuv handles the network io operations using native async mechanism of OS, if not available then it will use thread pool

topics.title: event loop
topics.note:
Event loop is basically a c program and it is part of the libuv

it coordinates between async and sync codes.

Execution order:

User written sync codes take priority over async codes, which means only after call stack is empty of sync code, the event loop pushes from the call back queue.

step 1: Any call backs in the micro task queue is executed. It contains two queues next Tick queue and Promise queue. priority is high for next Tick queue

step 2: callbacks in the timer queue executed

step 3: again, it will check the micro task queue and if any callback it there then it will execute that.
 
step 4: callbacks in the I/O queue will be executed
step 5: again, it will go back to microtask queue
step 6: callbacks in the check queue executed.
step 7: again, it will go and check the microtask queue.
step 8: callbacks in close queue executed
step 9: again, it will go and check the microtask queue.

if all the callbacks in the queues are executed then event loop exits.

micro task queue is used to queue the tasks that are expected to complete quickly and often related to promises.

nextTick queue is specific to NodeJS and not available in browsers.

one of the use cases of nextTick queue is to split the sync codes to number of async process.nextTick codes so that long running synchronous codes won't block the async codes for long time.

Another is to prevent the stack from overflow
topics.title: microtask queue

topics.note: IO events are polled and callback functions are added to the IO queue only after the IO is complete

topics.note: setImmediate() is used to queue a callback in check queue

topics.title: close queue
topics.note: close queue callbacks are executed after the queues in the given event loop iteration

The differnce between synchronous file read and asynchronous file read
topics.note: "Synchronous file operations block the execution of subsequent code until the operation completes. In contrast, asynchronous file operations are non-blockingâ€”Node.js offloads them to the OS using libuv, allowing the event loop to continue executing other tasks. Once the file operation is complete, the OS notifies Node.js, which then queues the callback in the event loopâ€™s I/O queue. The callback executes in the next event loop cycle, ensuring efficient handling of file operations without blocking the main thread."

topics.note:
A JavaScript function that takes inputs called props and return JSX elements that specifies what to be rendered in UI.

functional components are stateless, but state can be added by using hooks such as useState, useReducers .

functional components are preferred in modern react because of easy to read and less boiler plate code and its compatibility with hooks which allows to manage the state and side effects more easily efficiently.

topics.title: What is props and how it differs from state?
topics.note:
Props are read only data passed from parent to child component.

They cannot be modified by the receiving component, and it is used to handle the dynamic data and configure the child component.

whenever the props change, it causes the component to re-render.


The states are more like a memory of the component and they can be used to store the values which will change over time or in response to the user interactions. whenever the state changes the component will be re-rendered.

the states can be modified by the component

topics.title: What are the advantages and limitations of using React?
Explain the concept of Virtual DOM in React
topics.note:
Virtual DOM is a lightweight JavaScript object representation of the actual DOM, and it exists entirely on the memory.

whenever the component re-renders react creates new virtual DOM and then Reacts diffing algorithms compare the old virtual DOM and new virtual DOM and identifies the minimal set of changes required in actual DOM. Also, this process is highly optimized to reduce the number of DOM manipulations.

Without virtual DOM if there are 100 list items and only one item changes then entire list will be updated in the DOM but with virtual DOM react can identify the only item which need to be updated in the Real DOM.

The virtual DOM allows react to batches the update and update only the necessary parts of the UI, significantly improve the performance.

In essence Virtual DOM acts as a layer of abstraction between the Real DOM and react components enabling efficient and performant UI updates

topics.title: What is JSX and why it is used in React
topics.note:
JSX stands for JavaScript xml which is syntax extension for the JavaScript to allows to write html like codes inside the JavaScript.

JSX is not a requirement to the react, but it makes the codes more readable and allow us to visualize the UI inside component

JSX is not part of standard JavaScript and thus need to be transpiled using tools like babel.

Features of JSX:

- allows to embed JavaScript expression using {}
- allows to pass attributes like html elements
- allows to conditionally render
- allows to use inline styles 
- allows to use JS loops and methods like map function makes easy to write codes
- allows to nest the elements

limitations:
 - the JSX need to be transpiled to the standard js code by suing babel
 - deeply nesting can make the code less readable

What is react fiber
topics.note:
React Fiber is a complete rewrite of Reactâ€™s reconciliation algorithm, introduced in React 16. It improves how React updates the UI, making it more efficient, flexible, and performant.

Before Fiber, React used a recursive reconciliation process, which could block the main thread, causing performance issues. Fiber introduced an incremental and interruptible rendering system to improve responsiveness.

React Fiber breaks down rendering into two main phases:

  Render Phase (Reconciliation Phase) â€“ Can be Interrupted
  Commit Phase â€“ Synchronous & Cannot be Interrupted

topics.note:
React hooks are special functions that allows to use state and manage side effects in react functional components.

In class components it was difficult to reuse the stateful logic and we have to rely on HOC and render props - which creates nested trees and wrapper hell issues making code less readable.

hooks allow to share the stateful logic across components in a cleaner and readable way.
topics.title: What are react hooks and why were they introduced?

topics.note:
useEffect and useLayoutEffect both are used for side effects management in functional component. The difference is in execution timings.

The useEffect hook executes after browser paints the screen and run asynchrnously without blocking the UI updates.

The useLayoutEffect hooks run after the DOM updates and before browser paints the screen .  This actually blocks the UI updates.

The useEffects are normally used for data fecthing and adding event listeners while useLayoutEffect hook is used to read and write layout information.

 -  measuring the dimensions of the DOM elements
 - making the updates the must happen before browser paints the screen to avoid flickering

topics.title: What is synthetic event in react
topics.note:
Synthetic event in react is wrapper around native event to ensure cross browser compatibility and make it more performance optimized.

The react pools the synthetic event object to avoid frequent memory allocations and garbage collection.
so if try to access the event object asynchronously we will get error.

we need to use event.persist() to tell react that do not reuse the event object.

Also react uses event delegation at the document level.
